Entry.Title: Union List of Serials
The solar granulation

Comments.Comment: R. J. Bray, R. E. Loughhead, C. J. Durrant.Second edition. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge - London - New York - New Rochelle - Melbourne - Sydney. 16+256 pp. Price £ 27.50, \partial 54.50, DM 126.00 (1984). ISBN 0-521-24714-4.Reviews in Astron. Tidsskr., Årg. 17, Nr. 2, p. 91 (1984); Sonne, Jahrg. 8, Nr. 30, p. 98–99; 1984 (@cwyi@R. Beck@cwqi@).Contents: Historical introduction. The morphology, evolution and dynamics of the granulation and supergranulation. An introduction to the theory of convection. The theory of astrophysical convection. Interpretation of the granulation and supergranulation.

Entry.Title: Sterne und Sternhaufen

Comments.Comment: C. Payne-Gaposchkin, translated by C. Köberl.Friedr. Vieweg & Sohn, Braunschweig - Wiesbaden. 6+230 pp. Price DM 49.50 (1984). ISBN 3-528-08486-3. For the English original see 26.003.108.Contents: Die ganze Welt ist eine Bühne— Die Galaxie. Einfach nur Schauspieler— Die Hyaden. Sternennahrung. Zuerst das Kleinkind— Die Vorhauptreihenentwicklung. Gewunden wie eine Schlange— Die Hauptreihe. Nach der Hauptreihe. Überriesen. Der Seufzer des Fusionsofens— Die Cepheiden. Rote Riesen. Die ältesten offenen Sternhaufen. Offene Sternhaufen und die Struktur der Galaxie. Die Kugelsternhaufen. Metallreiche Kugelsternhaufen und rote Veränderliche. Kugelsternhaufen und kurzperiodische Veränderliche. Die letzte Szene? Finale— Pas de Deux.

Entry.Title: Planetary nebulae. A study of late stages of stellar evolution

Comments.Comment: S. R. Pottasch.Astrophysics and Space Science Library, Volume 107. D. Reidel Publishing Company, Dordrecht— Boston— Lancaster. 9+322 pp. Price Dfl. 115.00, $ 43.00 (1984). ISBN 90-277-1672-2.Contents: History, morphology and evolution. Distribution of planetary nebulae in the galaxy. Interpretation of emission lines and nebular abundances. Nebular continuum emission. Distance to the nebulae. Morphology, expansion and mass loss. The temperature of the central stars. Infrared and millimeter radiation. Evolution of the central star. Evolution from red giant to planetary nebula. Influence of planetary nebulae on the interstellar medium.

Entry.Title: Stellar atmospheric structural patterns

Comments.Comment: R. N. Thomas.Monograph Series on Nonthermal Phenomena in Stellar Atmospheres. Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Paris, France; National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Scientific and Technical Information Branch, Washington, D.C., NASA SP-471, 34+369 pp. Price FF 160 cloth, FF 100 paper (1983). ISBN 2-222-03402-7 cloth, ISBN 2-222-03403-5 paper.Contents: Part I: Thermodynamic overview of the stellar atmosphere. (1) Introductory comments on stellar atmospheric structure and its modeling. (2) Speculative-theoretical modeling of the atmosphere enveloping a hypothetical (closed, thermal) star. (3) Empirical-theoretical survey of the varieties of peculiarities and anomalies in the atmospheres enveloping actual stars. Part II: Thermodynamic and gas-dynamic background (following volume). Part III: Radial structure of atmosphere and local environment. (4) Characteristics of distinctive regions comprising stellar atmospheres. (5) Observed distinctive radial sequences of the distinctive atmospheric regions comprising stellar atmospheres. (6) Inferences on the thermodynamic characteristics of a star from the distinctive radial sequences of the distinctive atmospheric regions comprising that stellar atmosphere.

Entry.Title: IRAS asteroid workshop number 3: report and recommendations. Workshop held at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, Calif. 22–24 May 1984

Comments.Comment: E. F. Tedesco (Editor).JPL D-1617. Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, Calif. 91109, USA. 6+139 pp. (1984).The measurement portion of the IRAS project was completed in November 1983. A third workshop reviewed the status of the asteroid section of the project. Three areas of concern were investigated in detail by the workshop: (1) ADAS (@cwyi@Asteroid Data Analysis System@cwqi@) design, (2) asteroid thermal modeling, (3) final asteroid data products and access to them. Three working groups were formed to study these topics. The reports of each of these groups are included in the present report.

Entry.Title: Milankovitch and climate. Understanding the response to astronomical forcing. Proceedings of a NATO Advanced Research Workshop, held at the Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory, Palisades, N.Y., USA, November 30— December 4, 1982

Comments.Comment: A. Berger, J. Imbrie, J. Hays, G. Kukla, B. Saltzman (Editors).NATO Advanced Science Institutes, Series C, Volume 126 (Part 1 + Part 2). D. Reidel Publishing Company, Dordrecht - Boston - Lancaster. Part 1: 34+510 pp. Part 2: 9+385 pp. Price (set) Dfl. 310.00, US\partial 117.00 (1984). ISBN 90-277-1791-5 (set).This meeting reviewed the Milankovitch theory of the origin of the Pleistocene ice ages. The theory states that the global climate fluctuations during the ice age cycles were due to variations of the incoming solar radiation— variations, which were caused by slow periodic changes in the geometry of the Earth's orbit. Of major importance in this context are the following changes in the Earth's orbit: (1) variations in orbital eccentricity with a period of 100000 a, (2) variations in obliquity with a period of 41000 a, (3) variations in the precession of the equinoxes with periods of 23000 a and 19000 a. The first session of the meeting assessed the accuracy of modern astronomical calculations of the Earth's orbit back to several million years into the past. The following sessions reviewed the geological results supporting the hypothesis that orbitally-driven climatic variations occurred both in pre-Pleistocene times and in the Pleistocene. The main focus of the meeting was a review of the progress made in understanding and modelling the physical mechanisms, by which the climate system responds to the calculated changes in the pattern of incoming solar radiation. Special sessions were devoted to: energy balance climate models; models with an ice sheet as well as an atmosphere and an ocean; oscillator models of climate with orbital forcing; conceptual models of climatic response to orbital variations; general circulation models. A final chapter summarizes the current state of the Milankovitch theory by presenting the concluding assessments of 30 researchers.The individual contributions within the subject scope of Astronomy and Astrophysics Abstracts are included in their corresponding categories— see abstracts 042.108, 042.109, 081.051— 081.059.
